member.name: T:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis
member.summary: Provides a set of extension methods to run analysis (only available with a Build Machine license) and to collect existing analysis results references.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.TryGetMostRecentAnalysisResultRef(NDepend.Project.IProject,NDepend.Analysis.IAnalysisResultRef@)
member.summary: Gets a reference to the most recent analysis result available for this .
member.returns: A value indicating if a most recent analysis result referece has been found for this .
member.param: The reference to the most recent analysis result or null if the method call returned false.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.GetAvailableAnalysisResultsRefs(NDepend.Project.IProject)
member.summary: Gets a collection of all analysis results available for this ordered by . descending.
member.remarks:
If . doesn't save historic analysis results, then the returned list will contain the most recent analysis result available for this , or nothing if no analysis result is available for this .
On a NDepend project with many analysis results available for years, it is performant wise to prefer calling instead of this method, because analysis results references are then lazy-resolved, per month.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.GetAvailableAnalysisResultsRefsGroupedPerMonth(NDepend.Project.IProject)
member.summary: Gets a collection of all analysis results available for this , grouped per months.
member.remarks:
If . doesn't save historic analysis results, then the returned list will contain the most recent analysis result available for this , or nothing if no analysis result is available for this .
On a NDepend project with many analysis results available for years, it is performant wise to call this method than calling , because analysis results references are then lazy-resolved, per month.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.BuildAnalysisResultRefFor(NDepend.Project.IProject,NDepend.Path.IAbsoluteFilePath)
member.summary: Create an object from a project, an analysis result file (.ndar extension) and a date.
member.remarks:
The analysis result is not loaded, only the reference to the analysis result is returned.
The . is inferred from the directy path if the analysis result parent directory path. NDepend stores historic analysis result in a folder hierarchy named after YYYY_MM and then sub folder DD_HH_MM_SS.
If the analysis result file is not stored in such folder, . is the last write date of the analysis result file.
member.param: The analysis result file path (.ndar extension).
member.returns: The analysis result reference.
member.exception: This exception is thrown if the analysis result file doesn't exist.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.LoadAnalysisResultFromFile(NDepend.Project.IProject,NDepend.Path.IAbsoluteFilePath)
member.summary: Loads the analysis result of a project from an analysis result file (.ndar extension).
member.returns: The analysis result loaded.
member.exception: If the analysis load fails, an AnalysisException with an informative message is thrown.
This exception is thrown if the analysis result file doesn't exist.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.LoadCodeBaseFromAnalysisResultFile(NDepend.Path.IAbsoluteFilePath)

member.param: The analysis result file path (.ndar extension).
member.returns: The code base snapshot.
member.exception: If the analysis load fails, an AnalysisException with an informative message is thrown.
This exception is thrown if the analysis result file doesn't exist.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.RunAnalysis(NDepend.Project.IProject,System.String)
member.summary: Runs a full analysis on this project, in-process and synchronously. (Only available with a Build Machine license).
member.remarks:
Calling this method will typically takes a few seconds, the time the analysis is performed.
The analysis result is persisted in the project.Properties. directory.
It is possible to run several analysis simultaneously on several threads in the same AppDomain.
member.param: (Optional) An id to identify the analysis result build by this call.
member.returns: The analysis result.
member.exception: Cannot run analysis without a Build Machine license.
The analysis execution failed. The InnerException contains additional information concerning the failure.
The string for is invalid. It must be trimmed, a length of maximum 64 characters, excluding characters that cannot fit in a file name \ / : * ? " > < |

A procedure delegate object invoked each time the current analysis run emits a new object.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.AnalyzeAssemblies(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.String})
member.summary: Analyze a set of assemblies, in-process and synchronously, and return a object. (Only available with a Build Machine license).
member.remarks:
Calling this method will typically takes a few seconds, the time the analysis is performed.
Internally, this methods creates a temporary project with the method and then call on this temporary project. It is possible to run several analysis simultaneously on several threads in the same AppDomain.
member.param: A collection of string that contains assemblies file paths.
member.returns: The analysis result.
member.exception: Problem with creating a temporary project.
Cannot run analysis without a Build Machine license.
The analysis execution failed. The InnerException contains additional information concerning the failure.
One of the string in is null.
One of the string in is not a valid absolute file path.
One absolute file path in doesn't exist.

member.returns: The analysis result.
member.exception: Cannot run analysis without a Build Machine license.

member.summary: This method compiles and runs all rules against . and returns all issues in an object.

member.name: M:NDepend.Analysis.ExtensionMethodsProjectAnalysis.ComputeIssues(NDepend.Analysis.IAnalysisResult,System.TimeSpan,NDepend.Issue.IssueReferenceRecord,NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeBaseView@,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{NDepend.Analysis.IIssueComputationLog}@)
member.summary: This method compiles and runs all rules on . and returns all issues in an object.
member.remarks:
The rules are the active rules found in the project .., the active rules in active rule file(s) referenced by this project, and the active rules found in ..
The issues debt is computed and formatted against this project .
Before running the rules, this method also computes the just-my-code from active code queries prefixed with notmycode, found in the same locations than the rules, and returns it through .
Returned sequence of contains plain-english logs that represent all problems found while compiling and executing rules. This includes rules compilation / execution errors, rules that rely on code coverage not available, rules that relies on diff not available.
member.param: The analysis result on which to compute the issues.
The code query execution time-out duration.
A value that indicates if each issue in the returned object references the corresponding query execution object.
The just-my-code object computed, against which rules have been executed.
A sequence of plain-english logs that represent all problems found while compiling and executing rules, and that can explain some unexpected issues state in the returned object.

An Id is made of maximum 64 characters, excluding characters that cannot fit in a file name \ / : * ? " > < |.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.FullCoveredAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare that a code element is 100% covered by tests.
member.remarks:
The code metric ICodeContainer. can be used to determine whether a code element is 100% covered by tests or not.
Having types 100% covered by tests is a good idea because the small portion of code hard to cover, is also the portion of code that is the most likely to contain bugs.
Usage of this attributes is checked with the two default code rules:
Types tagged with FullCoveredAttribute should be 100% covered
Types 100% covered should be tagged with FullCoveredAttribute
If you don't want to link NDepend.API.dll, you can use your own FullCoveredAttribute and adapt the rules.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.FullBranchCoveredAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare that a method is 100% branch covered by tests (branch coverage is only available with NCover and OpenCover).
member.remarks:
The branch coverage code metric is only available with NCover.
The code metric IMethod. can be used to determine whether a method is 100% branch covered by tests or not.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all method tagged with this attribute are indeed 100% branch covered by tests.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all method 100% branch covered by tests are tagged with this attribute.

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.FullBranchCoveredAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.MoreThan95PercentCoveredAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare that a code element is more than 95% covered by tests.
member.remarks:
The code metric ICodeContainer. can be used to determine whether a code element is more than 95% covered by test or not.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all code elements tagged with this attribute are indeed more than 95% covered by tests.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all code elements more than 95% covered by tests are tagged with this attribute.

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.MoreThan95PercentCoveredAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.UncoverableByTestAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare that a code element is not coverable by tests.
member.remarks:
This attribute is useful to keep a class deemed as 100% covered by tests, even if one of its methods is not coverable by tests (for example because it calls a blocking method such as MessageBox.Show()).
This attribute is typically defined through .

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.UncoverableByTestAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare a code rule (or query) in your source code.
member.remarks:
The code rule is a CQLinq or CQL string.
It is extracted automatically from assemblies analyzed at analysis time.
A code rule gathered from a appears under a group named: "Rules extracted from Source Code".
Under this rule, code rules are grouped under the parent namespaces of code elements tagged by .
More information at Rules extracted from code

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, from the specified .
member.remarks: When declaring a code rule in source file, you can use one of the tags $FullName$ or $Name$ to paste in the rule string the of the code element tagged or the of the member (type/method/field) tagged.
member.param: The string that contains the CQLinq or CQL code rule or query.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.CodeRuleString
member.summary: Gets the CQLinq or CQL code rule string or query string.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.Active
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the code rule is active.
member.remarks: The default value is true.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.DisplayListInReport
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether if the code rule is violated, the code rule matched code elements are listed into the report.
member.remarks: The default value is true.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.DisplayStatInReport
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether if the code rule is violated, the code rule matched code elements statistics are shown into the report.
member.remarks: The default value is true.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.DisplaySelectionViewInReport
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether if the code rule is violated, the code rule matched code elements are shown in a treemap picture embedded into the report.
member.remarks: The default value is false.

member.name: P:NDepend.Attributes.CodeRuleAttribute.IsCriticalRule
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the code rule is critical or not.
member.remarks:
The default value is false.
A critical code rule is useful to break the build process once the rule is violated.
More information at: Critical Rules and Build Failure

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.ImmutableAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare a type as immutable.
member.remarks:
A class or structure is immutable if its instance object's state, cannot be modified after it is created. This is in contrast to a mutable object, which can be modified after it is created.
The property IType. can be used to determine whether a type is immutable or not.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all types tagged with this attribute are indeed immutable.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all immutable types are tagged with this attribute.

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.ImmutableAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.PureAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to declare a method as pure.
member.remarks:
A method is pure if it cannot be called in a way to provoque a side-effect.
The properties IMethod. and IMethod. can be used to determine whether a method is pure or not.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all methods tagged with this attribute are pure.
A code rule is provided by default to continuously make sure that all pure methods are tagged with this attribute.
Since .NET v4, you can also use the attribute type System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute declared in mscorlib (only for VS projects on which Microsoft Code Contract is enabled, else the PureAttribute is discarded by the compiler).

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.PureAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.CannotDecreaseVisibilityAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to signify that despite a member could have a lower visibility without provoking any syntax error, your intention is to not change this member visibility.
member.remarks:
Default Visibility code rules take account of this attribute.
Compare IMember. and IMember. values to detect members whose visibility can be decreased.

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.CannotDecreaseVisibilityAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.Attributes.IsNotDeadCodeAttribute
member.summary: This attribute can be used to signify that despite a member could be removed without provoking any syntax error (we also say it is dead code), your intention is to not remove this member.
member.remarks:
Some code rules are provided by default to match dead types, methods and fields, except those tagged with this attribute.
Typically, this attribute is useful when the code element :
is only used by tests
is only used for debugging purposes
is only used by reflection or remoting, like for some serialization methods
is a class that contains only constants, hence it is never used in IL code, and it is never seen as used by NDepend
is a field whose only need is for LayoutKind.Sequential reasons

member.name: M:NDepend.Attributes.IsNotDeadCodeAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsProjection
member.summary: Provides a set of extension methods to realize projection of a sequence of code elements to a sequence of children or parents code elements.
member.remarks:
All output sequences contain distinct code elements objects, even upon input sequence containing doublons code elements objects.
Sequences returned are ordered this way: all assemblies objects first (if any), then all namespaces objects (if any), then all types objects (if any), then all methods objects (if any), then all fields objects (if any).
Some OrderByHierarchy() and OrderByName() extension methods are also provided by this class to order result sequence differently if needed.

member.name: M:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsProjection.ParentTypes(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{NDepend.CodeModel.IMember})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of objects, containing all objects of all objects contained in this sequence .
member.remarks:
For a object in the sequence , a parent type is added to the result sequence only if it is a nested type.
If such a type is nested in a nested type all its parents types are added to the result sequence.
If the parent type of a nested type is already in the sequence , it is not added a second time because all sequences returned by projection methods are doublon-free.

member.name: M:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsProjection.NestedTypes(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{NDepend.CodeModel.IType})
member.summary: Returns a sequence of objects, containing all types nested in types of the sequence .
member.remarks:
If a type has a nested type that has a nested type, both nested types are returned.
Notice that for third-party nested types, the property . is set to true, but the parent/nested relation represented by . and . is not resolved. Hence this extension method only works for application types, not for third-party types.

member.name: M:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsHelpers.GetNbLinesOfCode_GuaranteedIfPDBFound(NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeElement)
member.summary: Try gets a number of lines of code for an application . This value is guaranteed not being zero if the code element is in an assembly for which PDB file has been found and parsed.
member.remarks:
The metric . is computed from number of sequence points obtained at analysis time when parsing a PDB file.
As a consequence, if a PDB file is not found, all associated objects have a null .
s However there are several cases where this metric is not defined for a code elements declared in an assembly with PDB file found:
- Abstract method
- Implicit constructor
- Field
- Interface
- Enumeration
- Namespace, assembly or code base that contains only interfaces and enumerations
This method is returning a non-null, non-zero value if satisfies the PDB found condition.
- This value is 1 for any abstract method, implicit constructor or field.
- In all other cases, is a object, and this methods returns + ..
Notice that in the peculiar case where is a , the PDB found condition means that a PDB file must have been resolved for all application assemblies at analysis time.
Notice that this method returns null for any third-party code element.
member.param: The code element for which we want to obtain the number of line of code

member.name: M:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsHelpers.TryGetSourceFileContent(NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeBase,NDepend.Path.IAbsoluteFilePath,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Try to get the content of a source file as it was at analysis time.
member.remarks:
If is true (which is the default value) source files get zipped at analysis time.
This method attempts to retrieve a source file content from this zipped store.
This method is different than trying to get the content from . Since the analysis has been executed the source file might have been edited or removed.
member.param: The code base that contains the source file.
The source file absolute path obtained from . or from ..
If this method succeeds and returns true, contains source file content.
If this method fails and returns false, contains a plain-english description of the failure.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsTooling
member.summary: Provides a set of extension methods to open source code elements declarations with a text editor tool (like Visual Studio), or even compare source declarations with a diff tool.

member.name: M:NDepend.CodeModel.ExtensionMethodsTooling.TryOpenSource(NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeElement)
member.summary: Opens the source file containing the declaration of this , and points to the declaration line.
member.remarks:
Code elements such as , or objects, often have multiple source declarations in the sequence .
In such a case, a dialog is shown to the user asking which declaration should be opened.
The source file declaration is opened in the editor tool defined through: NDepend > Options panel > Source File Editor Tool
This method can only be invoked within a .NET Framework 4.x and Windows OS context else it throws a NotSupportedException.
member.returns: true if the source declaration was opened successfully.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly
member.summary: Represents an application assembly, or a third-party assembly used by one or several application assemblies.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.FilePath
member.summary: Gets this assembly main module file path, found during analysis.
member.remarks: The returned reference is null if the assembly is true. In such case the third-party assembly hasn't been found and has been inferred from references.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.VisualStudioProjectFilePath
member.summary: Gets this assembly corresponding Visual Studio project file path, if found at analysis-time, otherwise gets null.
member.remarks:
NDepend uses an heuristic to try to infer the Visual Studio project file corresponding to this assembly.
This facility is only supported for C# project so far.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.Version
member.summary: Gets the assembly version, the version specified with the System.Reflection.AssemblyVersionAttribute attribute.
member.remarks: If the version is not specified, the version "0.0.0.0" will be returned.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.TargetFrameworkName
member.summary: Gets the target framework name (TFM) of the assembly.
member.remarks:
Returns a string such as 'net5.0', 'net5.0-windows', 'netcoreapp3.1', 'netstandard2.0', 'net462', 'net4x'.
Related documentation: https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2020/net5/net5.md
The string "Not available" is returned for third-party assemblies. This is because the NDepend third-party assemblies resolution logic can differ in some situations from the CLR resolution logic and the value returned could be wrong.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.TargetPlatform
member.summary: Gets the target platform of the assembly (Any CPU, x86, x64...).

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.CompanyName
member.summary: Get the string value of the attribute System.Reflection.AssemblyCompanyAttribute, or empty string if this assembly hasn't such attribute.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.PublicKeyToken
member.summary: Get the hexadecimal upper string value of the PublicKeyToken, or empty string if this assembly is not signed.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.ContainsNamespaceDependencyCycle
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this application assembly contains a dependency cycle between its . Gets null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
member.remarks:
The result of this property getter is lazy computed.
The first time it is called it has a O(this..Count ^2) time complexity.
Further calls result in a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.AssembliesUsed
member.summary: Gets a sequence of assemblies that this assembly is using. If this assembly is a third-party assembly, gets an empty sequence.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.AssembliesUsingMe
member.summary: Gets a sequence of assemblies that are using this assembly.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.PDBFound
member.summary: Gets a boolean value that indicates if the PDB file for this assembly has been found at analysis time.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.NbTypes
member.summary: Gets the number of types declared in this assembly. Gets null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.NbNamespaces
member.summary: Gets the number of namespaces declared in this assembly. Gets null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.Abstractness
member.summary: Gets a float numeric nullable value in the range [0,1] assessing the ratio of the number of internal abstract types (i.e abstract classes and interfaces) to the number of internal types.
member.remarks:
Abstractness=0 indicates a completely concrete assembly and Abstractness=1 indicates a completely abstract assembly.
More information concerning the usefulness of this code metric is available in the descripion of the code metric.
Availability:
A null numeric value is returned for any third-party assembly.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.Instability
member.summary: Gets a float numeric nullable value in the range [0,1] assessing an value of the assembly's resilience to change..
member.remarks:
The Instability value for an assembly is equal to the ratio of the incoming coupling () to the total coupling ( + ).
This metric is an indicator of the assembly's resilience to change.
The range for this metric is 0 to 1, with Instability=0 indicating a completely stable package and Instability=1 indicating a completely instable package.
More information concerning the usefulness of this code metric is available in the descripion of the code metric.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.DistFromMainSeq
member.summary: Gets a float numeric nullable value equals to / Sqrt(2), assessing the balance between and for this assembly. A returned value close to 0 indicates an ideal balance.
member.remarks: More information concerning the usefulness of this code metric is available in the descripion of the code metric.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.NormDistFromMainSeq
member.summary: Gets a float numeric nullable value in the range [0,1] assessing the balance between and for this assembly. A returned value close to 0 indicates an ideal balance.
member.remarks:
Abstractness versus Instability Metrics:
By measuring coupling between types of your application, NDepend assesses the stability of each assembly.
An assembly is considered stable if its child types are used by a lot of types of others application assemblies (i.e stable = painful to modify).
If an assembly contains many abstract types (i.e interfaces and abstract classes) and few concrete types, it is considered as abstract.
Thus, NDepend helps you detect which assemblies are potentially painful to maintain (i.e concrete and stable) and which assemblies are potentially useless (i.e abstract and instable).
This theory and metrics have been first introduced by the excellent book Agile Software Development: Principles, Patterns, and Practices in C#, Robert C. Martin (Prentice Hall PTR, 2006).
Distance from main Sequence definition:
It represents the perpendicular normalized distance of an assembly from the idealized line A + I = 1. A stands for Abstractness and I for Instability. This line is called main sequence.
This metric is an indicator of the assembly's balance between abstractness and instability. An assembly squarely on the main sequence is optimally balanced with respect to its abstractness and stability.
Ideal assemblies are either completely abstract and stable (I=0, A=1) or completely concrete and instable (I=1, A=0).
The range for this NormDistFromMainSeq metric is 0 to 1, with D=0 indicating an assembly that is coincident with the main sequence and D=1 indicating an assembly that is as far from the main sequence as possible.
A picture provided within the NDepend report reveals if an assembly is in the zone of pain (I and A both close to 0) or in the zone of uselessness (I and A both close to 1).
Recommendations:
Assemblies where NormDistFromMainSeq is higher than 0.7 might be problematic. However, in the real world it is very hard to avoid such assemblies.
Therefore, you should allow just a few of your application assemblies to violate this 0.7 threshold.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.RelationalCohesion
member.summary: Gets a float numeric nullable value assessing this assembly child types average cohesion.
member.remarks:
Let R be the number of types relationships that are internal to this assembly (i.e that do not connect to types outside the assembly).
Let N be the number of types within the assembly.
H = (R + 1)/ N. The extra 1 in the formula prevents H=0 when N=1.
The relational cohesion represents the relationship that this assembly has to all its types.
Recommendations:
As classes inside an assembly should be strongly related, the cohesion should be high. On the other hand, too high values may indicate over-coupling.
A good range for RelationalCohesion is 1.5 to 4.0.
Hence, assemblies where RelationalCohesion < 1.5 or RelationalCohesion > 4.0 might be problematic.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.NbTypesUsingMe
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value counting types outside this assembly using a child type of this assembly.
member.remarks: More information concerning the usefulness of this code metric is available in the descripions of the and code metrics.
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IAssembly.NbTypesUsed
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value counting types outside this assembly used by child types of this assembly. Third-party types are taken account in this cout.
member.remarks:
More information concerning the usefulness of this code metric is available in the descripions of the and code metrics.
s
member.returns:
null if this assembly is a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this assembly numeric value.

., available in CQLinq through the predefined field Application.
., available in CQLinq through the predefined field ThirdParty.
.., available in CQLinq through the predefined field JustMyCode. The JustMyCode code base view represents code elements that are not matched by any queries prefixed with the CQLinq keyword notmycode (.).
A custom can be created through the method ..

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer
member.summary: Represents a code element that can contain executable code. This interface is implemented by , , , and .
member.remarks:
This interface implements because contains executable code per definition, and executable code can used code elements.
A object doesn't necessarily contain executable code. For example an abstract method object, is a , that is a , yet an abstract method doesn't contain executable code.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.NbILInstructions
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value counting the number of IL instructions for this code element.
member.remarks:
The number of IL instructions can vary depending if an application assembly is compiled in debug or in release mode.
Indeed compiler's optimizations can modify the number of IL instructions.
For example a compiler can add some nop IL instructions in debug mode, to handle Edit and Continue, or to allow attaching an IL instruction to a curly brace.
member.returns:
null if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
null if this code element is an interface, an enumeration or an abstract method.
Otherwise returns the number of IL instructions for this code element.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.NbLinesOfCode
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value counting the number of logical lines of code for this code element.
member.remarks:
This metric (known as LoC) can be computed only if PDB files are present.
NDepend computes this metric directly from the information provided in PDB files.
The LoC for a method is equal to the number of sequence points found for this method in the PDB file.
A sequence point is used to mark a spot in the IL code that corresponds to a specific location in the original source.
More info about sequence points can be found here
Notice that sequence points which correspond to C# braces{ and } are not taken account.
Computing the number of lines of code from PDBs sequence points allows to obtain a logical LoC of code instead of a physical LoC (i.e directly computed from source files).
Two significant advantages of logical LoC over physical LoC are:
Coding style doesnt interfere with logical LoC. For example the LoC wont change because a method call is spawn on several lines because of a high number of arguments.
Logical LoC is independent from the programming language. Values obtained from assemblies written with different languages are comparable and can be summed.
Notice that the LoC for a type is the sum of its methods LoC, the LoC for a namespace is the sum of its types LoC, the LoC for an assembly is the sum of its namespaces LoC and the LoC for a code base is the sum of its application assemblies LoC.
Here are some observations:
Interfaces, abstract methods and enumerations have a NbLinesOfCode value equals to null. Only concrete code that is effectively executed is considered when computing LoC.
Namespaces, types, fields and methods declarations are not considered as line of code because they dont have corresponding sequence points.
When the C# or VB.NET compiler faces an inline instance fields initialization, it generates a sequence point for each of the instance constructor (the same remark applies for inline static fields initialization and static constructor).
LoC computed from an anonymous method doesnt interfere with the LoC of its outer declaring methods.
The overall ratio between and LoC (in C# and VB.NET) is usually around 7.
Recommendations:
Methods where NbLinesOfCode is higher than 20 are hard to understand and maintain.
Methods where NbLinesOfCode is higher than 40 are extremely complex and should be split in smaller methods (except if they are automatically generated by a tool).
member.returns:
null if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
null if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
null if this code element is an interface, an enumeration, an abstract method or a default constructor.
Otherwise returns the number of logical lines of code for this code element.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.NbLinesOfComment
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value counting the number of lines of comments contained in the body of this code element.
member.remarks:
This metric can be computed only if assemblies PDB files are found at analysis-time and if corresponding source files can be found.
So far this metric is only computed for C# code and a VB.NET version will be released in the future.
The number of lines of comment is computed as follow:
For a method, this metric value is the number of lines of comment that can be found in its body. In C# the body of a method begins with a '{' and ends with a '}'. If a method contains an anonymous method, lines of comment defined in the anonymous method are not counted for the outer method but are counted for the anonymous method.
For a type, this metric value is the sum of the number of lines of comment that can be found in each of its partial definition. In C#, each partial definition of a type begins with a '{ and ends with a '}'.
For a namespace, this metric value is the sum of the number of lines of comment that can be found in each of its partial definition. In C# each partial definition of a namespace begins with a '{ and ends with a '}'.
For an assembly, this metric value is the sum of the number of lines of comment that can be found in each of its source file.
Notice that this metric is not an additive metric (i.e for example, the number of lines of comment of a namespace can be greater than the number of lines of comment over all its types).
Recommendations:
This metric is not helpful to assess the quality of source code from a commenting perspective. Prefer using the metric .
member.returns:
null if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
null if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
null if the source code file path referenced from the PDB file cannot be found.
null if the source code of this code element is written with a programming language different than C#.
Otherwise returns the number of comments for this code element.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.PercentageComment
member.summary: Gets a numeric float nullable value in the range [0,100] assessing the percentage of comments for this code element.
member.remarks:
This metric value is computed with the following formula: = 100* / ( + ).
Recommendations:
Code where the percentage of comment is lower than 20% might need to be more commented. However overly commented code (more than 40%) is not necessarily a blessing as it can be considered as an insult to the intelligence of the reader.
Guidelines about code commenting can be found here.
member.returns:
null if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
null if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
null if the source code file path referenced from the PDB file cannot be found.
null if the source code of this code element is written with a programming language different than C#.
Otherwise returns the comments percentage for this code element.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.CoverageDataAvailable
member.summary: Gets a boolean value that indicates if coverage data is available for this code element.
member.returns:
false if no code coverage data are imported through the NDepend project settings .
false if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
false if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
false if the code element is tagged with an attribute that excludes elements from coverage statistics.
false if the code element does not contain any PDB sequence point. else returns true.
This property returned boolean flag is the inverse value of .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.PercentageCoverage
member.summary: Gets a numeric float nullable value in the range [0f,100f] assessing the percentage of comments for this code element.
member.remarks:
Recommendations:
The closer to 100%, the better!
member.returns:
null if no code coverage data are imported through the NDepend project settings .
null if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
null if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
null if the code element is tagged with the attribute defined in ..
null if the code element does not contain any PDB sequence point.
0 if the code element is 0 and the code element contains at least one PDB sequence point (opening/closing braces have sequence points but don't count as lines of code).
Otherwise returns the code coverage by tests percentage for this code element computed as / ( + ). Notice that if a code element parent (assembly/namespace/type) contains some child code elements tagged with . the lines of code of these child code elements are not counted neither in nor in .
As a consequence ( + ) can be lower than .
As a consequence a code element can have 100% code coverage, even if is lower than , as long as value is 0.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.IsExcludedFromCoverage
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this assembly, namespace, type or method dont have associated coverage data.
member.remarks:
This property returns:
true if no code coverage data are imported through the NDepend project settings .
true if this code element is defined in a third-party assembly.
true if the PDB file of this assembly or code element parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
true if the code element is tagged with an attribute that excludes elements from coverage statistics.
true if the code element does not contain any PDB sequence point. else returns false.
This property returned boolean flag is the inverse value of .
Unlike the property , this property also returns true for code elements whose coverage data is not available in coverage files provided - but that are not explicitly excluded from coverage.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeContainer.ExcludedFromCoverageStatistics
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this assembly, namespace, type or method is explicitly excluded from coverage.
member.remarks:
This property returns true for code elements matched by the <CodeCoverage> exclusion section within the .runsettings file provided (if any).
No matter the coverage technology used, methods and types tagged with 'System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExcludeFromCodeCoverageAttribute' are excluded from coverage statistics.
For the VS coverage technology, tagging a method or a type with 'System.Diagnostics.DebuggerNonUserCodeAttribute' or 'System.Diagnostics.DebuggerHiddenAttribute' exclude it also from coverage statistics.
You can also specify a custom attribute to excluded elements from coverage statistics in the Project Propeties > Analysis > Coverage > Settings form.
Unlike the property , this property returns false for code elements whose coverage data is not available in coverage files provided - but that are not explicitly excluded from coverage.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeElement.UniqueID
member.summary: Gets an integer identifier for this code element, unique in the scope of this .
member.remarks: This code element's unique identifier might be useful in situations where a unique hash code per code element, unique in the scope of this , is needed.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeElement.Name
member.summary: Gets a string representing the name of this code element.
member.remarks:
In case of a code base, the name is equal to the ...
In case of a type the name is TypeName<T> not prefixed with the parent namespace name.
In case of a nested type the name is OutterTypeName+TypeName<T> prefixed with the parent type name but not prefixed with the parent namespace name.
In case of a method the name is MethodName<T>(parameters types) not prefixed with the parent namespace name or parent type name.
In case of a field the name is FieldName not prefixed with the parent namespace name or parent type name.
In case of a namespace the name is simply the namespace name like N1.N2.N3.
The anonymous namespace of an assembly has a equals to the empty string.
In case of an assembly the name is the assembly main module file name, without file extension.
This property getter has a constant time complexity.
member.returns: The name of this code element.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.ICodeElement.FullName
member.summary: Gets a string representing the full name of this code element.
member.remarks:
If this code element is a , the full name is NamespaceName.TypeName<T>.
If this code element is a nested , the full name is NamespaceName.OutterTypeName+TypeName<T>.
If this code element is a , the full name is NamespaceName.TypeName.Method<T>(parameters types).
If this code element is a , the full name is NamespaceName.TypeName.FieldName.
If the parent namespace is the anonymous namespace, the full name begins directly with TypeName....
If this code element is a or an returns this..
This property getter has a constant time complexity.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.IField
member.summary: Represents a field declared in an application assembly, or declared in a third-party assembly and used the by application code.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.MethodsUsingMe
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods that are using this field. A field is considered as used if it is read or assigned.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.MethodsAssigningMe
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods that are assigning this field.
member.remarks:
For an instance field, constructor(s) of its class that assign the field are not counted.
For a static field, the class constructor that assigns the field is not counted.
This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.MethodsReadingMeButNotAssigningMe
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods that are reading this field but not assigning it.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count + this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.FieldType
member.summary: Gets the field type of this field. Gets null if the field type of this field is not in the scope of assemblies analyzed defined by ..
member.remarks: This property getter has a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.IsEnumValue
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this field is a value of an enumeration.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.IsEventDelegateObject
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this field is an event delegate object. C# and VB.NET compilers define for each event an event adder, an event remover, and a field typed with a delegate class.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.IsLiteral
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this field is declared with the const keyword in C# and the Const keyword in VB.NET.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.IsInitOnly
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this field is declared with the readonly keyword in C# and the ReadOnly keyword in VB.NET.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.IsImmutable
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this field is immutable.
member.remarks:
A static field is considered as immutable if it is private and if it is only assigned by the static constructor.
An instance field is considered as immutable if it is private and if it is only assigned by its types constructor(s) or its types static constructor.
Fields with a true value for , or are never considered as immutable to avoid noise in the search for immutable fields.
A field with a true value for is always considered as immutable.
In addition, a field with a true value for can be safely marked as readonly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.SizeOfInst
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this field contribution, in bytes, to the parent's . value.
member.remarks:
Size of Instance code metric description:
SizeOfInst for an instance field with a reference type field (class, interface, delegate) counts for 4 bytes.
SizeOfInst for an instance field with a value type field (structure, int, byte, double...) is equal to the value type . value.
SizeOfInst for a static field is null.
member.returns:
null if this field is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this field is static.
Otherwise returns this field numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IField.NbMethodsUsingMe
member.summary: Gets the number of methods that use this field.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember
member.summary: Represents a member code element. This interface is implemented by , and .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.Visibility
member.summary: Gets a value representing the visibility of this member.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.OptimalVisibility
member.summary: Gets a value representing the optimal visibility this member could have.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.ParentType
member.summary: Gets the parent type of this member.
member.remarks:
This property getter has a constant time complexity.
If this member is a type not nested in another type, this property returns null.
If this member is an application type nested in another type, this property returns the parent type.
Notice that for third-party nested types, the property . is set to true, but the parent/nested relation is not resolved. Hence for a third-party nested types, null is returned by this property.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.ParentNamespace
member.summary: Gets the parent namespace where this member is declared in.
member.remarks: This property getter has a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.ParentAssembly
member.summary: Gets the parent assembly where this member is declared in.
member.remarks: This property getter has a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsPubliclyVisible
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is publicly visible outside of its declaring assembly.
member.remarks:
Being a publicly visible member is a stronger condition than just having the property getter equals to true..
Indeed, it is common that a public member is declared in an internal type, in which case the member is not publicly visible.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsPublic
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as public.
member.remarks: See the condition if you wish to assess if a member is publicly visible outside of its declaring assembly.s

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsPrivate
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as private.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as internal in C#, or Friend in VB.NET.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsProtected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as protected.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsProtectedAndInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as protected and internal. This visibility level is provided by the IL language but is not supported neither by C# nor VB.NET.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsProtectedOrInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as protected internal in C#, or Protected Friend in VB.NET.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsStatic
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is a static method or field, or a static type.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsSpecialName
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member has a name that requires special handling, in the sense defined by System.Type.IsSpecialName and System.Reflection.MethodBase.IsSpecialName.
member.remarks:
Typically methods with special names are constructors, properties/events/indexers accessors, explicit interface method implementation.
Fields with special names is the instance field named value__ generated for each enumeration.
>

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsGeneratedByCompiler
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member has been generated by the compiler. This situation typically results from the compiler implementing lambdas, anonymous methods and iterators.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.IsObsolete
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is tagged with System.ObsoleteAttribute.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.ShouldBePublic
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is used outside of its declaring assembly thanks to the attribute System.Compilers.Services.InternalsVisibleToAttribute.
member.remarks: Often, having code elements that are considered as is not a problem because it is made on purpose. However, it can be interesting to list them.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.CouldBeInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as public, but could be declared as internal in C# (Friend in VB.NET) within the context of the analyzed application.
member.remarks:
A public code element can be declared as internal if it is not used outside of the assembly it is declared in.
When analyzing a framework, many of public members will be considered as because there is no analyzed client code using them.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.CouldBeInternalProtected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as public, but could be declared as protected internal in C# (Protected Friend in VB.NET) within the context of the analyzed application.
member.remarks:
A public member can be declared as protected internal (reads protected or internal) if it is not used outside of the assembly it is declared in and if it is not used outside of the classes that derive from the class it is declared in.
When analyzing a framework, some of the public members will be considered as because there is no analyzed client code using them.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.CouldBeProtected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member is declared as public, but could be declared as protected in C# (Protected in VB.NET) within the context of the analyzed application.
member.remarks: A public member can be declared as protected if it is not used outside of the classes that derive from the class it is declared in.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMember.CouldBePrivate
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this member could be declared as private in C# (Protected in VB.NET) within the context of the analyzed application.
member.remarks: A member can be declared as protected if it is not used outside of its parent class.

member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods declared in this method ., overriding this method. If this method is not overridden, gets an empty sequence.
member.remarks:
A sequence of methods overriding this method is also returned even if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
Methods for which is true, are not in the returned sequence.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.OverridesDirectDerived
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods declared in this method ., overriding this method. If this method is not overridden, gets an empty sequence.
member.remarks:
A sequence of methods overriding this method is also returned even if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
Methods for which is true, are not in the returned sequence.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.OverriddensBase
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods declared in this method . and , overridden by this method. If this method doesn't override any method, gets an empty sequence.
member.remarks:
A sequence of methods overridden by this method is also returned even if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
This property getter has a O(this...Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.Overloads
member.summary: Gets a sequence of methods declared in this method ., sharing the same with this method. The sequence returned doesn't contain this method.
member.remarks:
If this method doesn't have any overload, gets an empty sequence.
If this method is declared in a third party assembly, gets an empty sequence no matter this method is overloaded or not.
Properties getters and are faster to invoke than this property getter and might be better suited in some situations.
This property getter has a O(this...Count) time complexity.

Certainly the best resource on the web about this new slot advanced topic is this stackoverflow Q&A
Internally, NDepend relies on this new slot value to compute the override/overriden methods sets in property getter , and .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.IsAsync
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method is asynchronous, declared with the keyword async.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.IsUsingPinning
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method contains unsafe code that is using pinning.

VB.NET does not support unsafe code but C# does.
In C#, pinning is generated through the fixed keyword.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ChangesObjectState
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method assigns an instance field of its parent type
member.remarks:
true can be returned also for a constructor or a class constructor method.
true is returned for a static method or a class constructor that modifies the state of an object passed by reference.
true is returned for an instance method of a type T that modifies an instance of T that is not the one referenced by the this reference.
Methods that ChangesObjectState complexify the program because they break type immutability (see .).

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ChangesTypeState
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method assigns a static field of its parent type.
member.remarks: true can be returned also for a constructor or a class constructor method.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ReadsMutableTypeState
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method reads a static field with a false value for .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ReadsMutableObjectState
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method reads an instance field with a false value for .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ReadsImmutableTypeState
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this method reads a static field with a true value for .

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ReadsImmutableObjectState

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.CyclomaticComplexity
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this method body complexity computed from source code.
member.remarks:
Cyclomatic Complexity code metric description:
The Cyclomatic Complexity (CC) is a popular procedural software metric equal to the number of decisions that can be taken in a procedure.
Concretely, in C# the CC of a method is 1 + {the number of following expressions found in the body of the method}:
if | while | for | foreach | case | default | continue | goto | && | || | catch | ternary operator ?: | ??
Following expressions are not counted for CC computation:
else | do | switch | try | using | throw | finally | return | object creation | method call | field access
Notice that the CC of a lambda method or an anonymous method is not counted when computing the CC of its outer method.
Recommendations:
Methods where CC is higher than 15 are hard to understand and maintain. Methods where CC is higher than 30 are extremely complex and should be split in smaller methods (except if they are automatically generated by a tool).
member.returns:
null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this method is abstract or is a default constructor.
null if the PDB file of this method parent's assembly, hasen't been found.
null if the source code file path referenced from the PDB file cannot be found.
null if the source code of this method is written with a programming language different than C#.
Otherwise returns this method body complexity computed from source code.
More information on this can be found at: Understanding NDepend Analysis Inputs
If source code CC is not available for a non-abstract method, the code metric . can be used instead.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ILCyclomaticComplexity
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this method body complexity computed from IL code.
member.remarks:
Methods IL Cyclomatic Complexity code metric description:
The . (CC) metric is language dependent. Thus, NDepend provides the metric ILCyclomaticComplexity (ILCC) which is language independent because it is computed from IL as:
1 + {the number of different offsets targeted by a jump/branch IL instruction}.
Experience shows that ILCC is a bit more larger than the source code CC. Indeed, a C# if expression yields one IL jump. A C# for loop yields two different offsets targeted by a branch IL instruction while a foreach C# loop yields three.
member.returns:
null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this method is abstract or is a default constructor.
Otherwise returns this method body complexity computed from IL code.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.ILNestingDepth
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this method body maximum nesting scopes depth.
member.remarks:
Methods IL Nesting Depth code metric description:
The metric Nesting Depth for a method is the maximum number of encapsulated scopes inside the body of the method. The metric IL Nesting Depth is computed from the IL code. Values computed are similar to what we would expect by computing them from the C# or VB.NET source code.
A testing condition with N conditions, such as if( i > 9 && i < 12), is considered as N scopes because it is possible to decompose such conditions into N atomic conditions.
When a method has a large number of case statements corresponding to a switch, the C# and VB.NET compiler generally produce optimizations while generating the IL. In such case, the IL Nesting Depth corresponding value might be slightly higher to what you would expect.
Recommendations:
Methods with a IL Nesting Depth value higher than 4 are hard to understand and maintain. Methods with a IL Nesting Depth value higher than 8 are extremely complex and should be split in smaller methods (except if they are automatically generated by a tool).
member.returns:
null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this method is abstract.
Otherwise returns this method body maximum nesting scopes depth.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.NbOverloads
member.summary: Gets the number of overloads of this method or this constructor. Gets 1 if this method is not overloaded. Gets null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
member.remarks:
Recommendations:
Methods where NbOverloads is higher than 6 might be a problem to maintain and provoke higher coupling than necessary.
This might also reveal a potential misused of the C# and VB.NET language that supports object initialization since versions C#v3 and VB9. This language feature helps reducing the number of constructors of a class.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.NbParameters
member.summary: Gets the number of parameters of a method. ref and out parameters are also counted. The this reference passed to instance methods in IL is not counted as a parameter.
member.remarks:
Recommendations:
Methods where NbParameters is higher than 5 might be painful to call and might degrade performance. You should prefer using additional properties/fields to the declaring type to handle numerous states.
Another alternative is to provide a class or structure dedicated to handle arguments passing. For example see the class System.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo and the method System.Diagnostics.Process.Start(ProcessStartInfo).

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.NbVariables
member.summary: Gets the number of variables declared in the body of this method. Gets null if this methods is abstract or if it is declared in a third-party assembly.
member.remarks:
Recommendations:
Methods where NbVariables is higher than 8 are hard to understand and maintain.
Methods where NbVariables is higher than 15 are extremely complex and should be split in smaller methods (except if they are automatically generated by a tool).

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.NbMethodsCalled
member.summary: Gets the number of methods this method is calling. Gets null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.NbMethodsCallingMe
member.summary: Gets the number of methods that call this method.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.Rank
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value assessing this method rank, computed by the original Google Parge Rank algorithm.
member.remarks:
A homothety of center 0.15 is applied to make it so that the average of all application methods.Rank is 1.
Recommendations:
Methods with high rank should be more carefully tested because bugs in such methods will likely be more catastrophic.
member.returns:
null if this method is declared in a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this method numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IMethod.PercentageBranchCoverage
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring the percentage of branch coverage by tests for this method.
member.remarks:
Branch coverage is a more accurate measure of code coverage than because it compensates for method complexity.
Since branch coverage is generated from the underlying opcodes, it often does not map cleanly to source code.
This means that it might be difficult to take branch coverage values and determine how to write tests that will improve coverage.
Availability:
Branch coverage is only available if your coverage data are imported from NCover coverage files and if the metric is available for this method.

member.name: T:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace
member.summary: Represents a namespace declared in an application assembly, or declared in a third-party assembly and used by the application code.
member.remarks: If N assemblies declare the same namespace, there are N objects with a common value, one object for each assembly that declares the namespace.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.ParentAssembly
member.summary: Gets the parent assembly of this namespace.
member.remarks: This property getter has a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.DirectChildNamespaces
member.summary: Gets a sequence of direct child namespaces of this namespace. For example child namespaces of the namespace AA.BB could be AA.BB.CC but not AA.BB.CC.DD.
member.remarks:
The anonymous namespace doesn't have any direct child namespace.
This property getter has a O(this...Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.ParentNamespaces
member.summary: Gets a sequence of parent namespaces of this namespace. For example parent namespaces of the namespace AA.BB.CC could be AA.BB and AA.
member.remarks:
The anonymous namespace doesn't have any parent namespace.
If the namespace AA.BB doesn't contain any type, it is not shown as a parent namespace of AA.BB.CC. Indeed, if a namespace doesn't contain any type, the NDepend code model doesn't contain an associated INamespace object.
This property getter has a O(this...Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.ParentNamespace
member.summary: Gets the parent namespaces of this namespace. Gets null if no parent namespace is found. For example the parent namespace of the namespace AA.BB.CC could be AA.BB but not AA.
member.remarks:
The anonymous namespace doesn't have any parent namespace.
If the namespace AA.BB doesn't contain any type, it is not shown as a parent namespace of AA.BB.CC. Indeed, if a namespace doesn't contain any type, the NDepend code model doesn't contain an associated INamespace object. In such case AA is deemed as being the direct parent namespace of AA.BB.CC.
This property getter has a O(this...Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.ContainsTypeDependencyCycle
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this namespace contains a dependency cycle between its . Gets null if this namespace is declared in a third-party assembly.
member.remarks:
The result of this property getter is lazy computed.
The first time it is called it has a O(this..Count ^2) time complexity.
Further calls result in a constant time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.NamespacesUsed
member.summary: Gets a sequence of namespaces that this namespace is using. If this namespace is declared in a third-party assembly, gets an empty sequence.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.NamespacesUsingMe
member.summary: Gets a sequence of namespaces that are using this namespace.
member.remarks: This property getter has a O(this..Count) time complexity.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.IsGeneratedByCompiler
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this namespace contains only types generated by the compiler.
member.remarks: Such namespace can be named for example Microsoft.CodeAnalysis or System.Runtime.CompilerServices.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.IsPublic
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this namespace contains at least one public type.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.IsInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this namespace contains only internal types.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.CouldBeInternal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this namespace has at least one child public type, but is not used by any namespace declared in another assembly.
member.remarks:
A public code element can be declared as internal if it is not used outside of the assembly it is declared in.
When analyzing a framework, many of public members will be considered as because there is no analyzed client code using them.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.NbTypes
member.summary: Gets the number of types declared in this namespace. Gets null if this namespace is declared in a third-party assembly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.NbNamespacesUsed
member.summary: Gets the number of namespaces this namespace is using. Gets null if this namespace is declared in a third-party assembly.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.INamespace.NbNamespacesUsingMe
member.summary: Gets the number of namespaces that use this namespace.

member.summary: Gets a sequence of parent type(s) in which this type is nested.

The first type in sequence is the type returned by this..
If the parent type is also nested, the second type in sequence if its parent type and so on.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.HasFinalizer

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.IsImmutable
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this type is immutable. A type is considered as immutable if its instance fields cannot be modified once an instance has been built by a constructor.
member.remarks:
A stateless type (i.e a type without any instance field) is considered as immutable.
A type with at least one non-private instance field is considered as mutable, because such a field can be eventually modified outside the type.
A class that derives directly or indirectly from a mutable type is considered as mutable.
Enumerations, static types, types defined in third-party assemblies and delegate classes are never considered as immutable. Although these types might match the definition of immutability, considering them as immutable would introduce noise when searching for immutable types.
Particularly, classes that derive directly or indirectly from a class defined in a third-party assembly that is not the System.Object class, is never considered as immutable.
Using the readonly C# keyword (ReadOnly in VB.NET) on your own instance field is a good way to achieve immutability.
Notice that if a type T has some instance fields that are of reference type, the object pointed by such a reference might be modified without breaking the immutability of T. We are talking of shallow immutability. It is still possible to break immutability by using the ref C# keyword (ByRef in VB.NET) to allow a tier method to modify the state of an instance field.
As .NET framework designers considered that the immutability of the class System.String can be broken using advanced means such as reflection or unsafe code, you should consider that using the C# keyword ref or reflection or unsafe code are advanced means to break immutability of your own types.
Immutable types are especially useful when you have to deal with multi-threading application. Indeed, accesses to instances of immutable types dont need to be synchronized because such objects cant be modified; hence all accesses are read-only accesses.
To enforce your classes and structures immutability, see the attribute class .

member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this type child methods additive source code complexity.

Availability:

Otherwise returns this type child methods additive source code complexity.
More information on this can be found at: Understanding NDepend Analysis Inputs

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.SizeOfInst
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this type's instance object footprint, measured in bytes.
member.remarks:
Size of Instance code metric description:
SizeOfInst for a class or a structure is defined as the sum of . values of its fields plus the size of instances of its base class.
SizeOfInst for a generic type might be erroneous because we cannot statically know the footprint of parameter types (except when they have the class constraint).
SizeOfInst for an enumeration is equal to the size of instances of the underlying numeric primitive type. It is computed from the enumeration's value__ instance field (all enumerations have such a field when compiled in IL).
SizeOfInst for a static class or an interface is null.
Recommendations:
Types where SizeOfInst is higher than 64 might degrade performance (depending on the number of instances created at runtime) and might be hard to maintain.
However this is not a rule since sometime there are no alternatives. For example, the SizeOfInst value for the System.Net.NetworkInformation.SystemIcmpV6Statistics .NET framework class is 2064 bytes.
Non-static and non-generic types where SizeOfInst is equal to 0 indicate stateless types that might eventually be turned into static classes.
member.returns:
null if this type is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this type is static or is an interface.
Otherwise returns this type numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.DepthOfInheritance
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value measuring this type's depth of inheritance.
member.remarks:
The depth of inheritance for a class directly deriving from System.Object class is equal to 1.
The depth of inheritance for a structure is equal to 2 since it derives from System.ValueType that derives from System.Object.
The depth of inheritance for an enumeration is equal to 3 since it derives from System.Enum that derives from System.ValueType that derives from System.Object.
Recommendations:
Types where DepthOfInheritance is higher or equal than 6 might be hard to maintain. However this is not a rule since sometime your classes might inherit from third-party classes that have a high depth of inheritance.
For example, the average depth of inheritance for .NET Framework classes that derive from System.Windows.Forms.Control is 5.3.
member.returns:
null if this type is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this type is static or is an interface.
Otherwise returns this type numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.Rank
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value assessing this type rank, computed by the original Google Parge Rank algorithm.
member.remarks:
When discovering a legacy application, type ranking naturally sorts application types by an order of importance. Hence this code metric can help focusing on most relevant types first.
A homothety of center 0.15 is applied to make it so that the average of all application types.Rank is 1.
Recommendations:
Types with high rank should be more carefully tested because bugs in such types will likely be more catastrophic.
member.returns:
null if this type is declared in a third-party assembly.
Otherwise returns this type numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.LCOM
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value assessing the class members cohesion, through the standard Lack of Cohesion Of Methods code metric.
member.remarks:
The single responsibility principle states that a class should not have more than one reason to change. Such a class is said to be cohesive.
A high LCOM value generally pinpoints a poorly cohesive class. There are two LCOM metrics.
The LCOM takes its values in the range [0-1].
The LCOM HS defined by (HS stands for Henderson-Sellers) takes its values in the range [0-2]. A LCOM HS value highest than 1 should be considered alarming. Here are algorithms used by NDepend to compute LCOM metrics:
LCOM = 1 - (sum(MF)/M*F)
LCOM HS = (M - sum(MF)/F)(M-1) Where:
M is the number of methods in class (both static and instance methods are counted, it includes also constructors, properties getters/setters, events add/remove methods).
F is the number of instance fields in the class.
MF is the number of methods of the class accessing a particular instance field.
Sum(MF) is the sum of MF over all instance fields of the class. The underlying idea behind these formulas can be stated as follow: a class is utterly cohesive if all its methods use all its instance fields, which means that sum(MF)=M*F and then LCOM = 0 and LCOMHS = 0.
Recommendations:
Types where LCOM > 0.8 and NbFields > 10 and NbMethods >10 might be problematic. However, it is difficult to avoid such non-cohesive types.
Types where LCOMHS > 1.0 and NbFields > 10 and NbMethods >10 should be avoided. Note that this constraint is stronger (hence easier to satisfy) than the constraint types where LCOM > 0.8 and NbFields > 10 and NbMethods >10.
member.returns:
null if this type is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this type is an interface or an enumeration.
Otherwise returns this type numeric value.

member.name: P:NDepend.CodeModel.IType.LCOMHS
member.summary: Gets a numeric nullable value assessing the class members cohesion, through the standard Lack of Cohesion Of Methods Henderson-Sellers code metric.
member.remarks: See the code metric definition for detailled explanations on the Lack of Cohesion Of Methods Henderson-Sellers code metric.
member.returns:
null if this type is declared in a third-party assembly.
null if this type is an interface or an enumeration.
Otherwise returns this type numeric value.
